subject: Mathematics
objectives: Use SOH-CAH-TOA to solve right triangles and apply unit circle values
Verify identities and solve basic trigonometric equations
Apply trigonometry to Ghanaian contexts: surveying, navigation, periodic models

lessons.title: Basic Trigonometric Ratios
lessons.text: Trigonometry relates **angles** to **sides** of triangles. For a right triangle, **SOH-CAH-TOA** defines sine, cosine, and tangent in terms of opposite, adjacent, and hypotenuse. Special angles (30°, 45°, 60°) have known exact values. The **unit circle** extends these definitions to all angles by placing a radius-1 circle on the coordinate plane. Cosine equals the x-coordinate and sine equals the y-coordinate of a point on the circle. Trigonometry supports real tasks in Ghana: estimating the height of a **Kakum canopy** tower, measuring distances in surveying, and analyzing periodic patterns such as tides or electrical signals.

lessons.title: Trigonometric Equations and Identities
lessons.text: Trigonometric **identities** simplify expressions and support solving equations. Core identities include sin^2θ + cos^2θ = 1, tan θ = sin θ / cos θ, and reciprocal identities. To solve equations like 2sin θ = 1, isolate the ratio and use known values or inverse functions, considering all solutions in [0°, 360°) or specified intervals. Applying identities such as angle sum or double-angle may be necessary. Always check for extraneous solutions. These skills support understanding wave phenomena and **radio frequency** calculations used in broadcasting.

lessons.title: Applications in Real Life
lessons.text: Trigonometry supports **surveying**, **navigation**, and **periodic modelling**. The **sine** and **cosine** functions model repeating behaviour such as tides, seasonal temperatures, and AC electricity. Surveyors use angle and distance measurements to determine inaccessible lengths using the **sine** or **cosine rules**. Sailors and pilots navigate bearings with trigonometric relationships. In Ghana, estimating distances across **Lake Volta** or the height of buildings often uses trigonometric techniques when direct measurement is impractical.
